content.description: Nice thin hands to an awkward crux where the crack widens out into a strange pod (harder than it looks from the ground). Then a fun hand-sized cruise to the top.
content.protection: TR from bolts
content.location: Obvious hand crack when you first get to the cliff.

content.description: Pretty standard lieback, finish left in crack (easier) or go straight up for an interesting face topout.
content.protection: TR from tree, be careful of loose rocks up there/under your rope/webbing.
content.location: To the left of the obvious chimney, which is to the left of the obvious hand cracks when you first walk up the trail to the beginning of the cliff-band.

content.description: Fun and powerful moves on the arete and over the bulge. Not sure why this ones been collecting moss.
content.protection: Extend the anchor pretty far below the lip.
content.location: Just to the right of searching for stars

content.description: climb the prominent arete between pre-school and happy man. This arete features two mantle moves that are separated by thin face climbing. the first mantle is by far the easier of the two but both take some balance and trickery to get through. the climb then finishes on the final 5 feet of the left variation of Pre-school.
content.protection: n/a TR from bolts for pre-school
content.location: directly to the right of happy man on the arete that separates Pre-school.

content.description:
If this had a better landing (or lower crux) it would be a classic highball boulder problem. The movement is excellent, and comes to a puzzling crux moving onto the slab (where it looks like it would be easy from the ground).

 Start from a thin low left hand pocket and right hand around the corner on a good opposing pocket. Squeeze your feet on and balance your way up the pillar to aforementioned onsight crux pulling onto the slab. Finish up the same 4 feet of easy crack as the adjacent routes.
content.protection: Toprope from bolts
content.location: Obvious pillar that creates two much easier cracks on either side.

content.description: Start up easy and obvious chalked pockets. Easy climbing leads to a leftish traverse at the overhang to the arete (crux). Also possible to move straight up over ulta-thin holds and reach the arete higher up (harder).
content.protection: TR bolts on top
content.location: Start just left of the "Second Crack" and to the right of "Wide Jam" on obvious chalked pockets. Near the start of the cliff

content.description:
High quality grunting in an awkward flare, face holds ease the difficulty some especially near the top. 

 While it is a well known fact that all chimneys are 5.8, I listed this one a little higher to help with self esteem issues in a sport climber town.

 If this was three times as tall it would be a classic. Still good fun, and a good place to hone awkward flared chimney skills.
content.protection: Shiny anchor bolts at the top. 2 BD 5s and a 6 to lead. Pants, sleeves.
content.location: Obvious flared chimney that is about 7-10 inches deep in the back. In line with the corner of a detached boulder that forms a 4th class chimney further back, and provides easy access to the top of the cliff.

content.description: Climb the left side of the flake using liebacks and fingerlocks. A little more strenuous than it looks from the ground, but not deserving of the 10b rating it gets in the Falcon guide.
content.protection: Really long slings from a tree, easiest if you're TR soloing.
content.location: The left side of the little alcove "The Psycho" is in.

content.description: Primarily thin hands into a short lieback section off the suspect flake up higher.
content.protection: TR from bolts on top, or lead with 2 BD #1s.
content.location: Obvious splitter, can't miss it.

content.description: Really easy and continuous lieback/stemming, with tons of face feet. Crux is how much do you trust those blocks at the top?
content.protection: TR from bolts for the face route to the right ("Searching for the Stars")
content.location: Just past the "Open Book" route. Identify based on the picture/surrounding routes.

content.description: Enjoyable sporty crack climbing, with face holds abounding.
content.protection: Finger sized cams/nuts. Or TR from bolts
content.location: Start right where an big boulder ends, almost touching the edge of the start. This crack is on a face by itself, around the corner to the right are some obvious wide cracks.

content.description: Start out with some face climbing and work into a fingers/layback crack higher. Requires surprisingly little crack technique.
content.protection: Finger sized gear + nuts, might be a little bit of a dangerous lead down low. Or setup a TR off the nice bolts at the top.
content.location: Near the far end of the cliff band. The rightmost of 3 finger-sized cracks, and just left of the obvious chalked-up arete climb.

content.description: Perfect hand jams up a steep crack just left of "Crescent Crack." Much less traveled, but very enjoyable in my opinion. If only it went on forever..
content.protection: TR from "Crescent Crack" bolts, watch out for the swing or don't fall. Directional highly recommended.
content.location: Just left of "Crescent Crack," start up on the boulder.

content.description: Starts thin hands and then transitions into a wide section then good hands in the back of a flare. All in all a nice route.
content.protection: TR from bolts
content.location: As you walk up the first, most obvious trail to the start of the cliff, this is the right of the two hand cracks.

content.description:
This is really an excellent line, continuous and sustained with one good rest in the middle.  

  Start on thin holds and move up in a straight line (harder),  

  or start slightly left (uphill) and use big sidepull pockets to join the direct start (easier).  

  Make a few dynamic moves to reach a big jug/ledge and mantle up. Move out right into more difficult and continuous terrain. Stellar.
content.protection: TR from bolts.
content.location: Ascend the obvious chalked pockets immediately to the right of "Stars next door"

content.description: Obvious lieback corner, really a nice route. Crux in the middle.
content.protection: Thin hand size cams, or TR from bolts above.
content.location: The last crack on the main cliffband.

content.description: Cupped hands to fists through a bulge, or lieback. Steep at the start, easy over the bulge to the top.
content.protection: Bolts for TR, or BD 3s and 4

content.description: This crack bears a striking resemblance to the Incredible Hand Crack and Indian Creek. Its thin hands to a slightly wider thrutchy finish (crux).
content.protection: Thin hands gear, or TR from the tree about 15' back. Looks like there were bolts at some point, now chopped.

content.description: Go up whichever way you want, liebacking the angling flake seemed most natural to me. One of the easier routes around, good for people lacking in crack technique.
content.protection: TR from bolts, or lead with wide cams.

content.description: Climb the wide crack on the right side of the pillar shared with Tick Tack.
content.protection: Cams or TR from tree.
content.location: Right side of pillar shared with Tick Tack. To the left of the obvious "The Psycho."

content.description: Nice splitter off the ground, and another at the top.
content.protection: Hand sized, or bolted TR anchor
content.location: Start on the right side of the apron-ish flake, shares finish and anchor with "Homer's Odyssey."

content.description: Follow obvious chalked holds just left of a boulder (much more difficult if one uses only the chalked holds, and contrives to avoid the chockstones/boulder), diagonally up and right to an obvious deep pocket, then straight up to anchors. Would not recommend as an onsight solo/boulder due to somewhat deceptive upper holds.
content.protection: TR from eye bolt directly above, backed up by anchor for the splitter around the corner.
content.location: Just around the corner from an obvious splitter finger crack, this is on the left face of the corner where the three big wide cracks are.

content.description: Climb just the hand crack at 5.7, or just the finger crack to the right at 5.9...Or just do whatever you want because you can.
content.protection: TR from bolts for "Cracked Dish," be sure to figure out some sort of directional. Or lead, watch out for loose rock.
content.location: Just right of the right start for "Cracked Dish."

content.description: The golden face between "Tight Squeeze" and "Hercules".  Almost dead center of the face, start on two head high pockets and make moves up to the flat ledges above. Move into the left facing rail then out right to a gaston crimp. From here move through the pockets of varying sizes straight up the slightly overhanging face. Technical and committing to the last move. TR anchors up top, but makes for an amazing boulder problem.
content.protection: TR Anchors

content.description: "This is a difficult but awesome right-facing arete."  There are two bolts for a TR over the right face. Crux comes after the halfway-ledge, where the solid arete hands contrast with thin feet. Easy top out and great route overall! (Route info from Rock Climbing Oregon Falcon Guide + my experience)
content.protection: Two bolts with hangars.
content.location: The obvious arete across from Crescent Crack.

content.description: Awkward start (crux), easy the rest of the way.
content.protection: TR bolts on top
content.location: Start on the right side of the big scary "Homer's flake" and join up with Open book.

content.description: Climb the left side of the scary hollow flake.
content.protection: Probably best to TR this one, best anchor is likely the same tree used for "The Psycho." Be gentle with the manzanita as you run your webbing through it
content.location: Immediately around right from "The Pyscho."

content.description: Climb the obvious crack, using some jams and a lot of face holds.
content.protection: A couple hand size pieces to lead, and a couple more for an anchor. Scramble off to the right. (Or walk around to setup a TR, trad gear required)
content.location: This route is on a separate block from the main wall, about 30 feet back towards the parking lot if you're walking from the first routes at the main wall. If walking from the parking lot, the first fainter trail up to the rocks takes you here. On the backside is a nice V0 crack with crux at the top.

content.description:
This is the obvious and imposing 5 to 7 inch overhanging offwidth crack, the rightmost of the three prominent wide cracks on the same wall. 

  It's like a really, really miniature version of "Big Guy" at the Creek, same sizes and everything. 

  Name and grade come from the Falcon guide, take with a grain of salt.
content.protection: Pants, long sleeves. a 4, 2 x 5s, 1 x 6 BD if you want to lead it. Wouldn't recommend pushing cams for too long because you are very close to the ground.
content.location: Rightmost wide crack on the wall of three wide cracks. Big wide crack, you can't miss it.

content.description: Nice hand-to-fist crack. Crux is where it widens up at the top. Likely harder for smaller hands.
content.protection: Use bolt anchor for "Pre-school" crack to the right. A #4 cam is highly recommended at the top as a directional due to swing potential.

content.description: A very enjoyable chimney to climb, with a nice variety of face holds to work with. Probably a good first chimney. Vastly easier or harder depending on which side of your body you put in. Have fun.
content.protection: TR from tree, be careful of loose rock
content.location: As you reach the beginning of the cliff coming up the first well-defined trail to it, this will be the obvious chimney to the left of two hand-ish size cracks.

content.description: Lieback your way up a windy wide-crack flake with good feet most of the way. Crux might be the top, but mostly just sustained.
content.protection: TR from bolts or lead with big cams.
content.location: Just left of Cerchunk Crack. It's the obvious flake.

content.description: Enjoy some fun liebacking/stemming as you pull through some bulges.
content.protection: Tips to finger sized gear. Or TR from bolt anchor, with some serious rope grooves, damn.
content.location: Immediately left of "Dew, Blood, Chalk." The leftmost of the three finger-ish sized cracks.

content.description: Essentially the same crack size as "Straight Split," but with more features for feet and additional hands. Be careful as the flakey edges are quite friable.
content.protection: TR from anchors directly above, or lead with thin hand size pieces.
content.location: Hand crack in the corner just to the right of "Straight Split." More towards the beginning of the cliff.

content.description: Fun, fairly sustained route. Mostly fingers to wide fingers.
content.protection: Finger size gear, or TR from bolts.
content.location: Next crack left of the obvious "Solstice." This is the middle of the three finger cracks here.

content.description: Starts out fists and quickly widens, surprisingly doesn't take all that much offwidth technique because it's over quickly.
content.protection: Bolts for TR, or cams..

content.description: Climb up either side of the apron-like pillar to a ledge, then up the short corner to the top. On the right side you can climb up either some easy (5.7) face, or up the hand crack and traverse--although it is more natural to just continue up this crack to the top.
content.protection: TR, or lead with fingers/thin-hand size gear.
content.location: Approximately halfway down the cliffband.

content.description: Climb up nice little pockets on balancy face moves. Bolts at top for easy setup.
content.protection: Top Rope on Bolts
content.location: Climbs face left of "Wide Jam"

content.description: Work your way up opposing edges/liebacks onto a ledge and through a short hand crack to the top.
content.protection: TR from a single eyebolt, back up with a tree.
content.location: Right of Flaky Jake, just left of the well-traveled 3 finger cracks area

content.description: A reachy start leads to a low crux full of pockets. Easier moves off wide crimps and jugs make a more straightforward top.
content.protection: Anchors for TR
content.location: Around the arete of Hercules. The base is marked by a foot high overhang.

content.description: Great hand jams in a crisp gritty crack, they're just a little hard to reach. Really a pretty neat climb.
content.protection: Hand sized cams.. or use the bolt anchors from the wide crack/chimney a few feet to the right and don't fall, it'd be a bit of a swing (directional recommended).
content.location: The leftmost and shortest of three wide climbs, this one seems much more seldom done.

content.description:
Difficult and sustained. Climb up faintly chalked holds and hard to see feet. 

 A couple ways to start, the most natural seems to be going from the chalked sloper up to a left hand side pull pinch, and then working up the shallow dihedral feature on the right.

 The first two thirds of the route is beautiful and delicate balance climbing on very thin pockets and edges.

 Reach a rest below the big overhanging bulge and power over it to the top.

 If this line was bolted, or had more convenient top rope bolts it would get climbed all the time.
content.protection: Single eye bolt above the route, backed up by the new 2 bolt anchor for "fingers through bulges" two feet to the left (climbers right). Watch out for the pine tree branches at the top.
content.location: 5 feet left of "fingers through bulges." Start one of several ways. I started with my left hand on the obvious left facing shallow corner, and right hand in a small pocket. You could also start left of this on some chalked holds and go from there.

content.description:
Definitely one of the best face routes at Meadow Camp. Start on slightly overhanging face holds just a few feet right of the start for "Solstice" and work up to an interesting traverse right and up to a big ledge.    From the ledge you have two choices: 

  1) move left and make a difficult balance move left around the arete, and continue up the left side reaching back around right when you get to the obvious pockets. With your right hand in the pockets, make a hard pull to a small pinch on the arete, then gain the top! (11d/12a) (Note: you do have to contrive slightly to keep yourself from reaching all the way over to the right edge when you gain the pockets, but otherwise this really is a pretty natural line) 

  Or:   2) Stay on the right side of the arete, moving up with one hand on each side of the pillar, utilizing heel hooks on both sides. (10d/11a) (this way also feels a little contrived since you aren't fully entering the crack on the right)
content.protection: Single eye bolt, easily backed up with the anchor for "Solstice" 3' away.
content.location: The striking arete just to the right of "Solstice."

content.description: Fun continuous movement right off the ground, working through unusually large features for meadowcamp. Good footwork is rewarded, gain a ledge and balance your way into position of the second (but much easier) crux-reaching the topout.  Could be a highball boulder problem if it was just the lower crux and a better landing.
content.protection: TR from eyebolts. If you're at the top of the cliff, these are the very next set of bolts after the bolts for those first couple cracks.
content.location: Walk around to the right from the first set of cracks you come to, this is the line in the middle of the first clean face you come to (maybe 50' around the corner). Identify based on the enticing 1' sloping ledge features (see photo).

content.description:
This is a short south and east facing basalt cliff band just a few minutes outside Bend in national Forest, best for top-roping. The cliffs are between 20 and 40 feet tall. There are bolted anchors at least every ten feet along the top of the cliff. Most obvious climbs follow cracks and/or corners of some kind, although the faces between can also be climbed. The climbing can be delicate or physical and is almost all vertical.  

  While you may not be able to get in as many pitches as in the gym, it is real rock, outside, often secluded and by the river. It gets pretty hot in summer due to the aspect although large pines shade a handful of the climbs.  

  Although some climbs were probably named at one point, the top rope anchors mean that you can really climb anything, anywhere and "routes" aren't really defined. There are no bolts for sport climbing, please don't bolt unless you are replacing existing anchors. It's a 30 foot cliff with cracks and everything has already been climbed a hundred times on TR and as high ball boulder problems. If you want to clip bolts go to Smith. 

  There are also some good boulders along the base and at the downstream end of the cliffs.
